title: Where to live in Bali

searchText: where to live in bali a practical way to choose areas in bali for families—what daily life feels like, tradeoffs, and which questions matter most. areas areas neighborhoods families ## quick start - if you're brand new to the idea, **sketch your timeline** (next 3 months vs next year). - shortlist **2–3 areas** before you overthink school or housing. - keep **official links** bookmarked for anything that changes fast (especially visas). - prefer decisions that reduce stress: **short test-stays, staged commitments, clear contracts**. ## the calm roadmap ### step 1: decide your timeline write down the earliest date you could arrive—and the latest date you'd still feel good about. ### step 2: shortlist areas use the [areas](/areas) hub to shortlist 2–3 places that match your family's pace and commute tolerance. ### step 3: plan visas from experience (not certainty) we shar

title: Camps & short-term programs

title: Costs & budgeting for a Bali move
description: A budgeting framework for families: what drives costs up or down, and how to compare options without guessing.
searchText: costs & budgeting for a bali move a budgeting framework for families: what drives costs up or down, and how to compare options without guessing. costs costs budget planning housing schools transport healthcare checklist ## quick start (the fast version) - build **ranges**, not perfect spreadsheets. bali pricing varies. - the biggest budget drivers are usually **housing + education + transport**. - decide your family’s “tradeoffs”: space vs location, driver vs scooters, eating out vs cooking. - use this copy/paste tool to estimate calmly: [family budget range planner](/resources/family-budget-range-planner). - include a buffer for deposits + setup (first month is rarely “average”). --- <div class="mt-6 overflow-hidden rounded-2xl border border-gray-200 bg-white"> <iframe src="https://www.instagram.com/p/dr4gyszew5d/embed" title="flexible childcare (empathy school)" loading="lazy" class="w-full" style="min-he

title: Housing: renting, neighborhoods, and realistic expectations

title: Visas & residency for families
description: Experience-based visa planning for families: what tends to be smooth, what changes often, and how to protect yourself.
searchText: visas & residency for families experience-based visa planning for families: what tends to be smooth, what changes often, and how to protect yourself. visas visas residency evoa agents scams official-links checklist ## quick start (the fast version) - start with **timeline + length of stay** (2 weeks, 2 months, 12 months). that choice drives everything else. - bookmark **official links** now (this is how you avoid stale advice): [official links](/official-links). - if you can, do a **short test stay first**, then decide on longer-term visas once you’ve seen daily life. - avoid anyone selling “**guaranteed approval**” or pressuring you to pay today. - use a simple tool to compare help: [visa agent comparison template](/resources/visa-agent-comparison-template). --- ## the calm way to think about visas visa rules are one of the most **changeable** parts of bali life — which is exactly why this hub is writ

title: Amed for families
description: A quiet coastal stretch in East Bali—beautiful and slow, but better for families who are happy with fewer services and more intentional routines.
searchText: amed for families a quiet coastal stretch in east bali—beautiful and slow, but better for families who are happy with fewer services and more intentional routines. east bali amed quiet coastal families slower areas neighborhoods ## quick take amed is a **quiet coastal option** that some families love for the slower pace. it tends to suit families who don’t need constant activities and services nearby. ## who this area fits - families who want a calmer, nature-focused lifestyle - parents who enjoy simple routines and quieter days ## tradeoffs - longer trips for some services and activities - transport planning matters (especially with younger kids) ## what to test - grocery and essentials route - clinic access and what you’d do in an emergency (plan, not panic) - internet reliability if you work remotely guide: [healthcare planning](/guides/healthcare-in-bali-for-families) ## next steps - [areas hub](/areas) - [start

title: Bali areas for teens: how to choose
description: How to shortlist Bali areas that support teens—connection, activities, independence, and a home base that can recharge.
searchText: bali areas for teens: how to choose how to shortlist bali areas that support teens—connection, activities, independence, and a home base that can recharge. housing & neighborhoods areas housing teens families activities test-stay ## quick take with teens, the “best” area is usually the one that supports: - independence (safe places to go) - social connection (community + activities) - reliable routines (school/learning, sports, clubs) - family sanity (commutes and traffic are still real) this guide gives you a way to shortlist 2–3 areas for a test stay and tours — without pretending there’s one perfect answer. ## what matters most for teens ### 1) connection (they need “their people”) teens do better when they can quickly find: - a sport or club - a creative community - a group they can join consistently ask: **“where will my teen make friends within 2–4 weeks?”** ### 2) safe independence independence in bali looks d

title: Bali areas for toddlers: how to choose
description: A parent-first way to shortlist Bali areas that work well with toddler routines—commutes, naps, heat, and daily life.
searchText: bali areas for toddlers: how to choose a parent-first way to shortlist bali areas that work well with toddler routines—commutes, naps, heat, and daily life. housing & neighborhoods areas housing toddlers families routines test-stay ## quick take with toddlers, the “best” area is usually the one that makes **daily life predictable**: - short trips (nap windows + traffic don’t mix) - easy access to basics (groceries, a clinic, a quiet café/park, a kids activity) - a home that stays cool enough for naps - a routine you can repeat even when you’re new this guide helps you shortlist 2–3 areas for a **test stay** — not “pick the perfect forever neighborhood.” ## what matters most for toddlers ### 1) commute and nap math if a typical errand turns into a 45–60 minute ride, it affects everything: - nap timing - snack timing - parent patience - the ability to say “yes” to small outings **rule of thumb:** choose an area where you

title: Bali arrival checklist (eVOA, Arrival Card, tourist levy)
description: A parent-friendly checklist for landing days—what to do before you fly, what to do at the airport, and what to double-check using official sources.
searchText: bali arrival checklist (evoa, arrival card, tourist levy) a parent-friendly checklist for landing days—what to do before you fly, what to do at the airport, and what to double-check using official sources. visas & entry visas entry evoa arrival-card tourist-levy checklist ## quick start (the calm version) 1. bookmark **official links**: [/official-links](/official-links) 2. prepare a **single “arrival folder”** (digital + printed): passports, return/onward, accommodation, insurance, kids’ documents. 3. decide your airport plan: **stroller**, **snacks**, **bathroom strategy**, **sim plan**, **cash plan**. 4. after landing: go slow, hydrate, and keep everything in one bag until you’re through. > safety note: we share experience and checklists — not legal or immigration advice. rules change. ## before you fly (24–72 hours) ### 1) confirm the current entry steps - open: [/official-links](/official-links) - check: - evisa / e‑voa portal - arrival card portal - bal

title: Bali safety basics for families (practical, not scary)
description: A parent-first safety checklist: traffic, water, sun, mosquitoes, and “small habits” that reduce risk without turning life into fear.
searchText: bali safety basics for families (practical, not scary) a parent-first safety checklist: traffic, water, sun, mosquitoes, and “small habits” that reduce risk without turning life into fear. safety safety families kids health traffic dengue ## quick start (high-impact habits) - treat **road safety** as the main daily risk. - make a **mosquito plan** (especially at dusk). - build a **sun + hydration** routine. - choose safe swimming spots and follow “two adult eyes” rules for young kids. ## 1) road safety (the big one) - assume traffic is unpredictable. - avoid late-night driving when you’re tired. - if you use scooters, treat helmets as non‑negotiable. - for school tours and early weeks, many families use drivers. guide: [family transport options](/guides/family-transport-drivers-scooters-cars) ## 2) water and food (simple rules) we don’t try to be perfect — we aim for consistency: - drink safe water (ask your accommodation wha

title: Banking & payments in Bali (cards, cash, and the calm approach)
description: A practical money setup for families: what to decide before you arrive, how to reduce fees, and how to avoid “we can’t pay” moments.
searchText: banking & payments in bali (cards, cash, and the calm approach) a practical money setup for families: what to decide before you arrive, how to reduce fees, and how to avoid “we can’t pay” moments. costs & money money banking payments budget logistics ## quick start - have **two ways to pay** (backup card). - keep a small amount of cash for small purchases. - don’t optimize everything on day one. related: [cost of living framework](/guides/cost-of-living-for-families-framework) ## step 1: decide your “family money system” a simple system many families use: - one “daily spending” card - one backup card kept separate - a small cash stash for simple purchases ## step 2: build a “first week” cash plan - airport day cash for basics - groceries and transport buffer - avoid carrying large amounts until you’re comfortable ## step 3: budget clarity beats perfect numbers if you haven’t already, start with a range-based approach: - [family budget ra

title: Cost of living in Bali for families: a decision framework
description: A budgeting framework that explains why costs vary—and how to compare options without guessing.
searchText: cost of living in bali for families: a decision framework a budgeting framework that explains why costs vary—and how to compare options without guessing. costs costs budget planning families ## quick take two families can live in the “same bali” and spend wildly different amounts. costs mostly come from: **housing expectations, transport style, and school/camp choices**. ## a useful budgeting framework ### step 1: write your non-negotiables examples: - walkable mornings - quiet at night - a kitchen that makes home meals easy ### step 2: choose your “big three” cost drivers for most families: - housing - school / learning - lifestyle (restaurants, activities, travel) ### step 3: build a range (not a single number) use a low / mid / high range so you can adapt. ## next steps - pillar: [costs](/costs) - pillar: [areas](/areas)

title: Culture in Bali with kids (a respectful, calm approach)
description: How families join cultural moments respectfully—what helped, what to ask locals, and what to watch out for.
searchText: culture in bali with kids (a respectful, calm approach) how families join cultural moments respectfully—what helped, what to ask locals, and what to watch out for. family life culture ceremonies family-life kids respect ## a calm principle (so you don’t overthink it) we’ve found the safest approach is: - **be a respectful guest**, - **ask locals what’s appropriate**, - and **avoid turning culture into a performance**. this guide is not a rulebook. culture differs by village and context. if you want a copy/paste version: [culture with kids: quick checklist](/resources/culture-with-kids-quick-checklist). --- ## quick start - start with **one** cultural touchpoint that’s easy for kids (song, language, small ritual). - when invited to ceremonies, **ask first**: “is it okay if we join/watch? where should we stand?” - keep it short for children (snacks + water + exit plan). --- ## what “respectful participation”

title: Family transport in Bali (drivers, scooters, cars)
description: A calm, safety-first way to think about transport with kids: when scooters make sense, when they don’t, and how many families use drivers or cars.
searchText: family transport in bali (drivers, scooters, cars) a calm, safety-first way to think about transport with kids: when scooters make sense, when they don’t, and how many families use drivers or cars. family life transport safety drivers scooters cars families ## quick start - for your first month, prioritize **low-stress, low-risk** transport. - treat scooters as a *choice*, not a default. - if you’re arriving soon: [bali arrival checklist](/guides/bali-arrival-checklist-evoa-arrival-card-levy) ## option 1: walkable living (the best “transport hack”) if you can choose an area where: - groceries are close - kids’ activities are close - you can do “small life” without commuting …your transport stress drops dramatically. start with: [bali areas for families](/areas) ## option 2: driver (especially for new families) a driver can help you: - get from airport to accommodation calmly - do housing viewings without chaos - manage school runs (even short-t

title: Finding community in Bali with kids (without forcing it)
description: A parent-first way to help kids make friends and help adults feel less isolated—using repetition, routines, and low-pressure anchors.
searchText: finding community in bali with kids (without forcing it) a parent-first way to help kids make friends and help adults feel less isolated—using repetition, routines, and low-pressure anchors. family life community friends routines family-life settling-in ## the principle (so you don’t overthink it) community in bali is rarely a single discovery. it’s usually built from **repetition**: - same places, - same times, - same people, …for long enough that everyone stops feeling like strangers. --- ## quick start (week 1–2) if you want your move to feel calmer quickly: 1) pick **one child anchor** (school/camp/class) that happens weekly. 2) pick **one parent anchor** (market/cafe/playground/co-working) you’ll repeat. 3) keep it small for 2 weeks—then expand. useful companion: - [first month setup checklist](/resources/first-month-setup-checklist) --- ## the 4 “community anchors” that work for most families ### 1) school pick-up (or camp pick-up) pi

title: Your first week in Bali: setup checklist for families
description: A practical first-week checklist: SIM, transport, routines, groceries, healthcare plan, and what to postpone.
searchText: your first week in bali: setup checklist for families a practical first-week checklist: sim, transport, routines, groceries, healthcare plan, and what to postpone. logistics logistics checklist families ## quick take your first week is not for “optimizing”. it’s for getting a calm baseline. ## first-week checklist - sim/esim + a stable data plan - a transport plan (driver, scooter, car—whatever fits your family) - grocery routine (one “default shop”) - a basic healthcare plan (where you go for minor issues) - a simple schedule for kids (sleep, food, outside time) ## what to postpone - perfect housing - perfect school schedule - perfect budget tracking ## next steps - [start here](/start-here) - [housing](/housing) - [areas](/areas)

title: Groceries & meal routines in Bali (family-friendly)
description: A parent-first approach to feeding your family in Bali: groceries, meal planning, and how to reduce decision fatigue when you’re new.
searchText: groceries & meal routines in bali (family-friendly) a parent-first approach to feeding your family in bali: groceries, meal planning, and how to reduce decision fatigue when you’re new. family life groceries routines food families planning ## quick start (reduce decision fatigue) - choose **3 repeat breakfasts** and **3 repeat dinners** for your first week. - keep a “safe snack bag” for outings. - build one reliable grocery shop route in your area. ## step 1: decide your family food baseline write down: - your kids’ “safe meals” - any allergies / sensitivities - your weekly rhythm (busy nights vs calm nights) ## step 2: do one “baseline shop” buy: - breakfast basics - snack basics - simple proteins - easy veggies/fruits ## step 3: add variety slowly once routine feels easy: - add new cafes or markets - add new recipes - add new snacks --- ## markets and the “bali rhythm” for many families, bali starts feeling like home when yo

title: Health insurance in Bali for families (how to choose coverage)
description: A practical framework for families: what questions to ask, what to confirm in writing, and how to avoid buying the wrong thing for your reality.
searchText: health insurance in bali for families (how to choose coverage) a practical framework for families: what questions to ask, what to confirm in writing, and how to avoid buying the wrong thing for your reality. healthcare insurance healthcare families emergencies planning ## quick start - decide your “comfort goal”: *catastrophic coverage*, *routine coverage*, or *full-service peace of mind*. - confirm in writing: - what’s covered - how claims work - where you can go for care - don’t buy coverage you don’t understand. related: [healthcare in bali for families](/guides/healthcare-in-bali-for-families) ## step 1: choose the type of coverage you actually want ### a) catastrophic-only good if: - you can self-fund routine visits - you mainly want protection from big surprises ### b) routine + emergency good if: - you expect regular clinic visits with kids - you want predictable costs ### c) premium peace of mind good if: - you want direct billing options - you wan

title: Healthcare in Bali for families: mindset + practical planning
description: How families typically think about clinics, emergencies, and insurance—without pretending to be medical authorities.
searchText: healthcare in bali for families: mindset + practical planning how families typically think about clinics, emergencies, and insurance—without pretending to be medical authorities. health health clinics insurance families ## quick take we’re not doctors. but families usually do better when they decide their “healthcare mindset” early: where you go for minor issues, where you go for emergencies, and what insurance choices make sense for your risk tolerance. ## practical planning - choose one clinic you trust for minor issues - know your emergency plan (location + transport) - keep a small “family medical summary” note in your phone - ask other parents what they do (patterns matter) ## next steps - pillar: [family life](/family-life) - pillar: [costs](/costs)

title: How to choose a visa agent in Bali (family checklist)
description: A practical checklist for choosing a visa agent safely—what to ask, what to verify, and what red flags look like.
searchText: how to choose a visa agent in bali (family checklist) a practical checklist for choosing a visa agent safely—what to ask, what to verify, and what red flags look like. visas visas agents safety checklist ## quick take most families don’t need the “perfect” visa agent. they need someone who is **clear**, **consistent**, and **honest about uncertainty**. if an agent communicates well, gives you a checklist, and explains what could go wrong (without drama), that’s usually a better sign than flashy marketing. ## the family checklist ### ask these questions - what visa pathway are you recommending, and **why** for our situation? - what documents do you need from us **before** you start? - what’s the full fee breakdown (agent fee + government fees + extras)? - what is the **realistic** timeline—and what commonly causes delays? - how will you communicate updates (whatsapp, email) and how often? ###

title: Lease and deposit questions to ask in Bali (before you pay)
description: A practical checklist for families: what to confirm in writing before paying a deposit or signing a lease, and which details cause the most stress later.
searchText: lease and deposit questions to ask in bali (before you pay) a practical checklist for families: what to confirm in writing before paying a deposit or signing a lease, and which details cause the most stress later. housing housing renting lease deposit contracts families ## quick start (copy/paste checklist) before you pay: - confirm who the legal signer is (owner/authorized agent) - confirm the payment schedule and currency - confirm what utilities are included - confirm maintenance responsibilities - confirm deposit return conditions - confirm how disputes are handled (in writing) related pillar: [housing & neighborhoods](/housing) ## the questions that save you stress later ### 1) “what exactly is included?” ask about: - electricity - water - internet - pool/garden maintenance - cleaning (if any) ### 2) “what happens if something breaks?” - who pays for repairs? - what’s the typical response time? - how do you report issues? ### 3) “how does the deposit g

title: Packing list for Bali with kids (what we’d bring again)
description: A practical packing guide for families relocating or test-staying in Bali—what’s easy to buy locally and what’s worth bringing.
searchText: packing list for bali with kids (what we’d bring again) a practical packing guide for families relocating or test-staying in bali—what’s easy to buy locally and what’s worth bringing. logistics packing kids logistics moving planning ## quick start - pack for the **first 2–4 weeks**, not forever. - prioritize sleep + sun + routines. - leave space for what you’ll buy once you understand your life here. ## essentials (the non-negotiables) - passports + documents (and copies) - basic meds you rely on (with appropriate documentation where needed) - kid comfort items (sleep toys, a familiar blanket) - sun hats + swim basics - a small “carry-on survival kit” for landing day ## family routine helpers - water bottles - lunch/snack containers - basic tech adapters and chargers - a small first-aid kit ## what we learned the hard way the best packing list is the one that supports routines. comfort matters when you’re building a new

title: Phones and internet in Bali (a family setup guide)
description: A simple connectivity plan for families: how to avoid landing-day stress, what to set up first, and what to test before you rely on it.
searchText: phones and internet in bali (a family setup guide) a simple connectivity plan for families: how to avoid landing-day stress, what to set up first, and what to test before you rely on it. logistics internet phone sim esim logistics ## quick start - decide your “arrival plan”: esim before you fly vs get a sim after you land. - test internet in your accommodation **before** you commit to routines that depend on it. - keep a backup: a second sim, hotspot plan, or “plan b café”. related: [bali arrival checklist](/guides/bali-arrival-checklist-evoa-arrival-card-levy) ## step 1: choose your arrival setup ### option a: esim before you fly pros: less stress, you land connected cons: you need to set it up calmly before travel ### option b: sim after arrival pros: flexible cons: landing day becomes more complicated ## step 2: internet reliability checklist (copy/paste) - speed test at morning + evening - video call stability tes

title: Quiet + nature areas in Bali: how to choose
description: A calm, realistic guide to choosing a quiet base in Bali—without accidentally isolating your family from services and community.
searchText: quiet + nature areas in bali: how to choose a calm, realistic guide to choosing a quiet base in bali—without accidentally isolating your family from services and community. housing & neighborhoods areas housing quiet nature families test-stay ## quick take if your family wants **quiet + nature** (and you’re okay with fewer “city conveniences”), bali can be amazing. but “quiet” is not a single place — it’s a set of tradeoffs: - less noise, fewer crowds - more intentional routines - sometimes longer trips for services this guide helps you choose a quiet base without accidentally isolating yourself. ## define what “quiet” means for your family quiet can mean: - less traffic and fewer scooters - a home base with green views - fewer nightlife distractions - cooler evenings (depends on elevation and breeze) write down your top two: 1) ______________ 2) ______________ ## areas that often suit quiet + nature (with tradeoffs) ### sidemen

title: Renting safely in Bali (questions to ask before deposits)
description: A parent-first renting guide: verification steps, contract questions, and a staged approach that reduces risk.
searchText: renting safely in bali (questions to ask before deposits) a parent-first renting guide: verification steps, contract questions, and a staged approach that reduces risk. housing housing renting safety checklist ## quick take renting can be straightforward—until it isn’t. the biggest risk isn’t “bali”; it’s **rushed decisions**. if you can: do a short stay first, view in person, verify identity, then sign. ## a staged approach (lower stress) 1. **short stay (7–21 days)** in your shortlisted area(s) 2. view 5–10 places quickly 3. verify: owner/agent identity, deposit terms, maintenance expectations 4. sign a clear agreement 5. move in, then optimize (don’t optimize first) ## questions to ask before deposits - who is the legal owner / manager? - what’s the exact deposit amount and refund policy? - what happens if utilities fail (water, electricity, internet)? - who pays for repairs, and what’s the res

title: The 2‑week test-stay plan (before you commit to Bali)
description: A practical test-stay plan for families—how to choose 2–3 areas, simulate routines, and avoid “holiday mode” decisions.
searchText: the 2‑week test-stay plan (before you commit to bali) a practical test-stay plan for families—how to choose 2–3 areas, simulate routines, and avoid “holiday mode” decisions. planning test-stay planning areas routines families ## quick start - pick **2–3 areas** using this: [area shortlist scorecard](/resources/area-shortlist-scorecard) - for each area, schedule: - one “work morning” - one “errands afternoon” - one “quiet evening” - do at least **one rainy day plan** (even if it’s dry season) related: [bali areas for families](/areas) · [where to live in bali (guide)](/guides/where-to-live-in-bali-for-families) ## step 1: decide what “good” means for your family write down your top 3: - calm mornings - walkable errands - community - green space - kid activities - commute simplicity - budget control then pick your “non-negotiable”: - *we can’t do daily heavy traffic*, or - *we need walkable basics*, or - *we need q

title: Ubud vs Sanur vs Canggu for families (how to choose)
description: A calm comparison: pace, routines, community, commute, and “what it feels like” day-to-day—so you can shortlist areas without overthinking.
searchText: ubud vs sanur vs canggu for families (how to choose) a calm comparison: pace, routines, community, commute, and “what it feels like” day-to-day—so you can shortlist areas without overthinking. areas areas ubud sanur canggu comparison families ## quick comparison (the vibe) - **ubud:** green, slower, more “inward,” great for families who want calmer routines - **sanur:** beach city energy, easier errands, often a calmer “base” - **canggu region:** international, busy, lots happening, more traffic and stimulation if you haven’t yet, start here: [area guides](/areas) ## how to decide (the only 3 questions that matter) ### 1) what pace makes your family calm? - do you love “always something on”? - or do you want quiet evenings and nature? ### 2) what commute stress can you tolerate? some families are fine with driving. others find it drains energy fast. ### 3) what does “community” mean for you? - international community and events?

title: Visa scam red flags (and how families protect themselves)
description: Anonymous, practical red flags that help families avoid scams without naming or accusing specific people.
searchText: visa scam red flags (and how families protect themselves) anonymous, practical red flags that help families avoid scams without naming or accusing specific people. visas visas scams safety parents ## quick take visa content attracts scammers because families are stressed and timelines feel urgent. the goal here isn’t fear—it’s a calm pattern-recognition checklist. we keep this anonymous on purpose: **no names, no accusations**—just red flags and what families do instead. ## red flags families watch for ### communication red flags - answers that stay vague after you ask the same question twice - “don’t worry about it” when you ask for a receipt or a written breakdown - constant urgency without clarity ### money red flags - a large deposit requested before you receive a written scope - “special discounts today only” - fees that change every time you ask ### authority red flags - “we hav

title: What to ask on a school tour (copy/paste checklist)
description: A copy/paste list of questions for school tours—learning support, safety, communication, community, and commute reality.
searchText: what to ask on a school tour (copy/paste checklist) a copy/paste list of questions for school tours—learning support, safety, communication, community, and commute reality. learning schools tours checklist parents ## quick take a tour is more than questions—it’s **watching the classroom feel** and mapping the commute in real time. copy/paste the checklist below into your notes app. ## copy/paste checklist ### learning & support - how do you support kids who are ahead / behind? - what does “support” look like day-to-day (not just on paper)? - how do teachers communicate progress? ### safety & supervision - what supervision ratios do you aim for? - what’s the protocol for injuries? - how do you handle pick-up and drop-off? ### community & fit - what kind of family tends to thrive here? - what’s the parent community like? - what do new families find hard in the first month? ### commute reality - what tim

title: Where to live in Bali for families: how to shortlist areas
description: A calm approach to choosing where to live: pace, noise, walkability, commute, and your family’s real priorities.
searchText: where to live in bali for families: how to shortlist areas a calm approach to choosing where to live: pace, noise, walkability, commute, and your family’s real priorities. areas areas neighborhoods families planning ## quick take most stress comes from commute + noise + mismatched expectations. a good shortlist is usually 2–3 areas. ## the shortlist method 1. pick your family pace: calm / mixed / busy 2. decide commute tolerance (in minutes, not feelings) 3. choose “daily-life priorities” (walkability, cafes, nature, community) 4. test-stay in two areas if you can ## recommended starting points browse the area guides: [areas hub](/areas) if you want a simple shortlist: - try **sanur** for calmer family routines - try **ubud** for nature + slower pace (some tradeoffs) - try **berawa/pererenan** if you want more international community (and accept more busy) ## next steps - pillar: [areas](/areas) - pilla

title: The 45,000‑Rupiah Miracle
description: How Bali quietly makes family life feel easy
searchText: the 45,000‑rupiah miracle how bali quietly makes family life feel easy family life family-life daily-life routines costs ubud by eric some mornings in bali start with a soundtrack you didn’t know you needed. a rooster somewhere in the distance. the soft clink of temple bells. a scooter humming past slowly—less “rush hour,” more “someone’s going to buy fruit.” incense drifting in from a tiny offering placed neatly on the edge of a driveway. my kids outside, barefoot, already inventing a game out of sticks and leaves and whatever the jungle decides to contribute that day. it’s the kind of scene people fly across the world to witness for a week. and yet the thing that still surprises me most isn’t the beauty. it’s the convenience. because in the background of all that calm—rice fields flowing like green water, the jun

title: 3 budgeting mistakes families make when planning Bali
description: A few common mistakes—and a calmer way to plan ranges instead of one fragile number.
searchText: 3 budgeting mistakes families make when planning bali a few common mistakes—and a calmer way to plan ranges instead of one fragile number. costs costs budget planning ## mistake #1: planning a single number a single number makes families anxious because reality moves. use a **range**. ## mistake #2: forgetting the big drivers housing expectations + learning costs + lifestyle are the main multipliers. ## mistake #3: underestimating “setup month” the first month often includes extra costs (transport, short stays, deposits, small fixes). ## a calmer approach use the [budget range planner](/resources/family-budget-range-planner). ## related - [costs](/costs) - [cost of living framework](/guides/cost-of-living-for-families-framework)

title: The calm decision that reduces Bali relocation stress
description: Before visas, before house hunting: the one decision that makes everything else easier for families.
searchText: the calm decision that reduces bali relocation stress before visas, before house hunting: the one decision that makes everything else easier for families. planning planning families stress ## written answer (always first) the calm decision is: **choose your timeline and your “test-stay plan”** before you try to optimize everything else. families who decide “we’ll do 2–4 weeks first, then decide” tend to: - make fewer rushed deposits, - choose areas based on real routines, - and feel less pressure to get the “perfect” visa path on day one. ## a simple test-stay plan - pick 2–3 areas to test - book short stays (7–10 days each) - act like you live there: groceries, commute, bedtime, errands ## next steps - [start here](/start-here) - [areas](/areas) - [housing](/housing)

title: Rainy season with kids: what changes (and what doesn’t)
description: Practical rainy season planning for families: routines, transport, and keeping kids regulated when the weather shifts.
searchText: rainy season with kids: what changes (and what doesn’t) practical rainy season planning for families: routines, transport, and keeping kids regulated when the weather shifts. family life family-life routines weather ## what changes - travel time (rain slows everything) - kids’ regulation (less outside time can show up fast) - plans (you learn to keep “indoor defaults” ready) ## what doesn’t - the importance of routines - the value of a calm commute - the need for one anchor community ## practical rainy-season defaults - one indoor activity you can do daily - a simple “wet day” transport plan - earlier afternoons (kids get tired) ## related - [family life](/family-life) - [first week checklist](/guides/first-week-in-bali-setup-checklist)

title: Why we shortlist 2–3 areas before anything else
description: Area choice shapes budget, routines, and school options. Here’s a simple way parents shortlist without overthinking.
searchText: why we shortlist 2–3 areas before anything else area choice shapes budget, routines, and school options. here’s a simple way parents shortlist without overthinking. areas areas planning families ## the short version area is a multiplier. it changes: - daily calm (noise + commute), - budget (rent + lifestyle), - and which learning communities are realistically accessible. ## the shortlist method (2–3 areas) 1. choose your pace: calm / mixed / busy 2. decide commute tolerance (minutes) 3. pick 3 daily-life priorities (walkability, nature, community, etc.) 4. test-stay if you can ## related - [where to live guide](/guides/where-to-live-in-bali-for-families) - [areas hub](/areas)

title: Video: How we run a school tour (what to look for)
description: A video walkthrough of what to pay attention to during a school visit: classroom feel, support, and commute reality.
searchText: video: how we run a school tour (what to look for) a video walkthrough of what to pay attention to during a school visit: classroom feel, support, and commute reality. video video schools tours parents ## written answer (always comes first) this page demonstrates the **video block** standard: - the written answer is on-page (seo + accessibility) - the video is supporting context - we include a transcript (or a detailed recap) - a clear, gentle next-step cta lives under the video ## what to look for on a tour - classroom energy and teacher attention - support systems (how help happens day-to-day) - supervision and safety routines - parent communication - commute reality at real times ## related - [tour checklist resource](/resources/school-tour-question-list) - [school tour guide](/guides/what-to-ask-on-a-school-tour)

title: Why I Feel So Safe Raising Kids in Bali
description: When families talk to me about moving to Bali, “Is it safe?” is usually the first real question.
searchText: why i feel so safe raising kids in bali when families talk to me about moving to bali, “is it safe?” is usually the first real question. family life safety family-life kids routines areas when families talk to me about moving to bali, “is it safe?” is usually the first real question. i understand it. safety isn’t a headline. it’s a daily feeling. it’s whether you can relax while your kids grow up. it’s whether ordinary life stays ordinary. so instead of trying to convince you with big statements, i’ll just share what safety looks like in our family’s day-to-day life here—simple routines, small rules, and a community that makes it easy to exhale. the best safety upgrade we made was… geography our house is near empathy school. that one detail changes everything. it means my kids can walk to school. it means mornings don’t start with traffic and rushing and stress. it means the

title: Area shortlist scorecard (2–3 areas)
description: A scorecard to shortlist areas based on your family’s real priorities: pace, commute, walkability, and community.
searchText: area shortlist scorecard (2–3 areas) a scorecard to shortlist areas based on your family’s real priorities: pace, commute, walkability, and community. planning areas neighborhoods planning ## scorecard rate each area 1–5. - pace / calm - commute tolerance - walkability - kid-friendly activities - parent community fit - noise (street-level, not “area-level”) ## tip don’t over-optimize before you arrive. pick 2–3, then test-stay. ## related - [areas hub](/areas) - [where to live guide](/guides/where-to-live-in-bali-for-families)

title: Arrival folder checklist (digital + printed)
description: A copy/paste checklist for your Bali arrival folder—documents and screenshots that reduce stress when you’re tired.
searchText: arrival folder checklist (digital + printed) a copy/paste checklist for your bali arrival folder—documents and screenshots that reduce stress when you’re tired. checklist arrival checklist visas planning families ## copy/paste list ### identity + travel - passports (all travelers) - passport photo pages (scans) - flight details (screenshots) - accommodation confirmation (screenshots) - return/onward proof (if needed) ### visas / entry (as applicable) - any approvals / receipts - links to official portals: [/official-links](/official-links) ### kids + family - birth certificate scans (optional but helpful) - any school letters (if relevant) - medical notes (if relevant) ### money + comms - backup card details (stored securely) - emergency contact list (offline) - address pinned in notes ## how we use it we keep: - one cloud folder - one offline folder on a phone - one small printed set (minimum pages)

title: Camp questions checklist (copy/paste)
description: A parent-first checklist for choosing camps and short-term programs in Bali—supervision, safety, refunds, communication, and fit.
searchText: camp questions checklist (copy/paste) a parent-first checklist for choosing camps and short-term programs in bali—supervision, safety, refunds, communication, and fit. template camps checklist template families ## copy/paste questions ### supervision (the most important section) - what’s the **adult-to-child ratio** for my child’s age group? - how do you handle supervision during **transitions** (arrival, bathroom, snack, moving between activities)? - who is the “home base” adult my child can return to if they’re overwhelmed? ### safety + health - what’s your protocol for **injuries**? (first aid, escalation, when parents are contacted) - what’s the plan for **illness** (fever, vomiting, etc.)? - do you have staff trained in first aid? - how do you manage **water safety** (if relevant)? ### allergies + medical needs - can you accommodate allergies? what’s the procedure to prevent cross-contact? - c

title: Culture with kids: quick checklist (Bali)
description: A parent-friendly checklist for joining cultural moments respectfully—without turning them into a performance.
searchText: culture with kids: quick checklist (bali) a parent-friendly checklist for joining cultural moments respectfully—without turning them into a performance. checklist culture families checklist family-life ## culture with kids (a calm, respectful approach) this is **experience-based guidance**, not an official authority. culture differs by village and context. when in doubt: **ask**, follow local guidance, and stay humble. ### before you go - **ask first:** “is it okay for us to join/watch?” - **dress modestly** (especially for temples/ceremonies): covered shoulders, respectful clothing, and follow local expectations. - **keep it simple for kids:** short duration, clear boundaries, snacks/water. - **bring a small offering/donation** if your local community suggests it. ### during cultural moments - **follow the flow:** stand where others stand, wait when others wait. - **don’t treat it like a

title: Family budget range planner (low / mid / high)
description: A simple framework to plan a Bali budget range instead of one fragile number.
searchText: family budget range planner (low / mid / high) a simple framework to plan a bali budget range instead of one fragile number. planning costs budget planning ## the range planner instead of one number, plan **low / mid / high**. ### step 1: choose your baseline lifestyle - home meals most days? - eating out most days? - travel every month? ### step 2: budget the big drivers - housing - learning (school/camps) - transport - healthcare/insurance buffer ### step 3: create your “stress test” ask: *if costs jump 20% for one month, are we okay?* ## related - [cost of living framework](/guides/cost-of-living-for-families-framework) - [costs](/costs)

title: Family transport plan (first month in Bali)
description: A simple worksheet to decide how your family will move around in the first month—walkability, driver use, car needs, and scooter boundaries.
searchText: family transport plan (first month in bali) a simple worksheet to decide how your family will move around in the first month—walkability, driver use, car needs, and scooter boundaries. worksheet transport planning safety families ## step 1: write your “stress rule” example: - “we avoid heavy traffic with tired kids.” - “we avoid night driving when possible.” your rule: - … ## step 2: choose your first-month default pick one: - walk + driver - car + walk - mixed (walk + driver + occasional scooter) ## step 3: scooter boundaries (if relevant) - who rides? - when (daytime only / not in rain / not with tired kids)? - safety gear rule: ## step 4: school/activities plan (even if you’re not enrolled yet) - how far are you willing to commute daily? - what’s your backup plan if traffic is heavy? related guide: [family transport in bali](/guides/family-transport-drivers-scooters-cars)

title: First month in Bali: calm setup checklist
description: A month-one checklist that focuses on calm routines before optimization.
searchText: first month in bali: calm setup checklist a month-one checklist that focuses on calm routines before optimization. checklist logistics checklist families ## the calm month-one checklist ### week 1: basics - sim/esim + stable data - transport plan - grocery routine - a basic clinic plan ### week 2: routines - sleep + food rhythm - one daily outside activity - one parent “anchor community” ### week 3–4: small upgrades - adjust commute - improve food defaults - add one extracurricular ## related - [first week setup checklist](/guides/first-week-in-bali-setup-checklist) - [family life](/family-life)

title: Lease + deposit checklist (copy/paste questions)
description: Use this checklist before paying a deposit or signing a lease in Bali—clarity now prevents stress later.
searchText: lease + deposit checklist (copy/paste questions) use this checklist before paying a deposit or signing a lease in bali—clarity now prevents stress later. checklist housing renting lease deposit checklist ## copy/paste questions ### people + authority - who is the owner / authorized signer? - can you show proof of authority to rent this property? ### money - total rent amount and currency - payment schedule (monthly / quarterly / yearly) - deposit amount and what it covers - how deposit return is calculated and when it’s returned ### what’s included - electricity included? if not, how is it billed? - water included? - internet included and what speed/provider? - pool/garden maintenance included? - cleaning included? ### maintenance - who fixes what? - typical response time? - what happens if internet/power is unreliable? ### exit + disputes - early exit policy - what happens if there’s a disp

title: School tour question list (copy/paste)
description: A copy/paste question list for school tours: learning support, supervision, communication, and commute reality.
searchText: school tour question list (copy/paste) a copy/paste question list for school tours: learning support, supervision, communication, and commute reality. template schools tours template parents ## copy/paste questions ### learning & support - how do you support kids who are ahead / behind? - how do you communicate progress to parents? - what does support look like day-to-day? ### safety & supervision - what supervision ratios do you aim for? - what’s the protocol for injuries? - how do you handle pick-up and drop-off? ### community & fit - what kind of child thrives here? - what do new families find hard in the first month? - how do you help kids make friends? ### commute reality - where do most families live? - what does traffic look like during rainy season? ## related - [what to ask on a school tour](/guides/what-to-ask-on-a-school-tour) - [schools & learning](/schools)

title: Visa agent comparison template (copy/paste)
description: A copy/paste template to compare 2–3 visa agents on clarity, fees, timelines, and trust signals.
searchText: visa agent comparison template (copy/paste) a copy/paste template to compare 2–3 visa agents on clarity, fees, timelines, and trust signals. template visas agents template checklist ## copy/paste table paste this into a doc or spreadsheet. | category | agent a | agent b | agent c | |---|---|---|---| | recommended pathway (and why) | | | | | fee breakdown (agent + government + extras) | | | | | timeline (best / typical / worst) | | | | | communication channel + response time | | | | | red flags noticed | | | | | trust signals (clarity, receipts, official links) | | | | | our gut feel after 2 calls | | | | ## what to watch for - clarity beats confidence. - if “guaranteed approval” appears, treat it as a red flag. ## related guides - [how to choose a visa agent](/guides/how-to-choose-a-visa-agent) - [official links](/official-links)
